ai-sn56:7.1.1_0: “Mendicants, don’t think bad, unskillful thoughts, such as
ai-sn56:7.1.4_0: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:7.2.1_0: When you think, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:7.2.3_0: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:7.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:7.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

ai-sn56:8.1.2_0: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-sn56:8.1.4_0: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

ai-sn56:8.2.3_0: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

ai-sn56:9.1.2_2: I understand this teaching and training.
ai-sn56:9.1.2_4: I stay on topic, you don’t.
ai-sn56:9.1.2_5: You said first what you should have said last.

ai-sn56:9.1.4_0: Because those discussions aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:9.2.1_0: When you discuss, you should discuss: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. ...
ai-sn56:9.2.2_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...”

ai-sn56:10.1.2_0: talk about kings, bandits, and ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.

ai-sn56:11.0.3_0: Rolling Forth the Wheel of Dhamma
ai-sn56:11.1.1_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling near Bārāṇasī in the Deer Park at Isipatana.
ai-sn56:11.1.2_0: There it was that the Fortunate One addressed the group-of-five monks, saying:
ai-sn56:11.2.1_0: “Mendicants, these two extremes should not be cultivated by one who has gone forth.
ai-sn56:11.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by two?
ai-sn56:11.2.3_0: Indulgence in sensual pleasures, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And indulgence in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
ai-sn56:11.2.4_0: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One woke up by understanding the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:11.3.1_0: And what is that middle way of practice?
ai-sn56:11.3.3_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn56:11.3.4_0: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:11.4.1_0: And this is noble truth of suffering:
ai-sn56:11.4.2_0: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; illness is suffering; death is suffering; association with the disliked is suffering; separation from the liked is suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
ai-sn56:11.4.3_0: Now this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.
ai-sn56:11.4.4_0: It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-sn56:11.4.5_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-sn56:11.4.6_0: Now this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:11.4.7_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-sn56:11.4.8_0: Now this is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:11.5.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn56:11.5.2_0: ‘This noble truth of suffering should be completely understood.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.5.3_0: ‘This noble truth of suffering has been fully understood.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn56:11.6.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.6.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.6.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering has been given up.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.7.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.7.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.7.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering has been realized.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.8.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn56:11.8.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.’ Such was the vision that arose in me ...
ai-sn56:11.8.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering has been developed.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn56:11.9.1_0: So long as my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was not fully purified in these three perspectives and twelve respects, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn56:11.10.1_0: But when my true knowledge and vision about these four noble truths was fully purified in these three perspectives and twelve respects, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-sn56:11.10.2_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-sn56:11.10.3_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
ai-sn56:11.10.4_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn56:11.10.5_0: The monks from the group of five were pleased and they rejoiced in the Buddha’s exposition.
ai-sn56:11.11.1_0: And while this exposition was being spoken, Venerable Koṇḍañña experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
ai-sn56:11.11.2_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-sn56:11.12.1_0: And when the Buddha rolled forth the Wheel of Dhamma, the earth gods raised the cry:
ai-sn56:11.12.2_0: “Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
ai-sn56:11.12.3_0: Hearing the cry of the Earth Gods, the Gods of the Four Great Kings ...
ai-sn56:11.12.4_0: “Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
ai-sn56:11.12.5_0: Hearing the gods of the four great kings, the Tāvatiṁsa gods cried out ...
ai-sn56:11.12.8_0: the gods who delight in creation ...
ai-sn56:11.12.9_0: the gods who control the creations of others ...
ai-sn56:11.12.10_0: the Brahmakāyika gods let loose a cry:
ai-sn56:11.12.11_0: “Near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana, the Buddha has rolled forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma. And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or Brahmā or by anyone in the world.”
ai-sn56:11.13.1_0: In that instant the news spread as far as the Brahmā world.
ai-sn56:11.13.2_0: And this galaxy shook and rocked and trembled. And an immeasurable, magnificent light appeared in the world, surpassing the glory of the gods.
ai-sn56:11.14.1_0: Then the Fortunate One uttered this inspired utterance:
ai-sn56:11.14.2_0: “Koṇḍañña has understood; indeed, Koṇḍañña has understood!”
ai-sn56:11.14.3_0: In this way Koṇḍañña got the name “Aññāsikoṇḍañña”, “Koṇḍañña who has understood.”
ai-sn56:12.1.1_0: “‘This is the noble truth of suffering.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in the Realized Ones regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn56:12.1.2_0: ‘This noble truth of suffering should be completely understood.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.1.3_0: ‘This noble truth of suffering has been fully understood.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.2.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the origin of suffering.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.2.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.2.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the origin of suffering has been given up.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.3.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.3.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.3.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the cessation of suffering has been realized.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.4.1_0: ‘This is the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.4.2_0: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.’ ...
ai-sn56:12.4.3_0: ‘This noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering has been developed.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in the Realized Ones regarding teachings not learned before from another.”
ai-sn56:13.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:13.1.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:13.2.1_0: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
ai-sn56:13.2.2_0: You should say: ‘The five grasping aggregates’.
ai-sn56:13.2.3_0: That is: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn56:13.2.4_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of suffering.
ai-sn56:13.3.1_0: And what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?
ai-sn56:13.3.2_0: It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure in various different realms. That is,
ai-sn56:13.3.3_0: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence.
ai-sn56:13.3.4_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the arising of suffering.
ai-sn56:13.4.1_0: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?
ai-sn56:13.4.2_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-sn56:13.4.3_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:13.5.1_0: Now what, monks, is the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering?
ai-sn56:13.5.4_0: This, monks, is called the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering.
ai-sn56:13.5.5_0: These are the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:13.6.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:13.6.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:14.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:14.1.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:14.2.1_0: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
ai-sn56:14.2.2_0: You should say: ‘The six interior sense fields.’
ai-sn56:14.2.4_0: The sense fields of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn56:14.2.5_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of suffering.

ai-sn56:14.3.2_0: It’s the craving that leads to future rebirth, mixed up with relishing and greed, looking for enjoyment in various different realms. That is,
ai-sn56:14.3.3_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the arising of suffering.
ai-sn56:14.4.1_0: And what is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering?
ai-sn56:14.4.2_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not adhering to it.
ai-sn56:14.4.3_0: This I say, monks, is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:14.5.1_0: Now what, monks, is the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering?
ai-sn56:14.5.4_0: This, monks, is called the Noble Truth of the Practice Leading to the Cessation of Suffering.
ai-sn56:14.5.5_0: These are the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:14.6.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...

ai-sn56:15.1.9_0: That’s how I remember the four noble truths as you’ve taught them.”

ai-sn56:20.1.1_0: “Mendicants, these four things are real, not unreal, not otherwise.
ai-sn56:20.1.6_0: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ ...
ai-sn56:20.1.7_0: These are the four things that are unreal, not otherwise.
ai-sn56:20.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:20.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:20.2.3_0: The second sub-chapter on teaching is finished.
ai-sn56:20.3.1_0: the Realized One, the perfected one,
ai-sn56:21.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis at the village of Koṭi.
ai-sn56:21.1.3_0: “Mendicants, not understanding and not penetrating four noble truths, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.
ai-sn56:21.2.5_0: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:21.2.6_0: But now, monks, the noble truth of suffering has been awakened to and penetrated, likewise the noble truth of the origin of suffering, the noble truth of the end of suffering, and the noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:21.2.6_1: Craving for continued existence has been cut off, what leads to rebirth has been exhausted,
ai-sn56:21.2.6_2: now there’ll be no more future lives.”
ai-sn56:21.3.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn56:21.3.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn56:21.4.3_0: You transmigrate for a long time
ai-sn56:21.4.4_0: from one rebirth to the next.
ai-sn56:21.5.1_0: But now that these truths have been seen,
ai-sn56:21.5.2_0: the attachment to rebirth is eradicated.
ai-sn56:21.5.3_0: The root of suffering is cut off,
ai-sn56:21.5.4_0: now there’ll be no more future lives.”
ai-sn56:22.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:22.1.2_0: I don’t regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.
ai-sn56:22.2.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:22.2.2_0: I regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”
ai-sn56:22.3.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn56:22.3.2_0: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
ai-sn56:22.4.1_0: “There are those who don’t understand suffering
ai-sn56:22.5.1_0: And they don’t know the path
ai-sn56:22.5.2_0: that leads to the stilling of suffering.
ai-sn56:22.5.6_0: they continue to be reborn and grow old.
ai-sn56:22.6.1_0: There are those who do understand suffering
ai-sn56:22.7.2_0: that leads to the stilling of suffering.
ai-sn56:22.7.3_0: They’re endowed with the heart’s release,
ai-sn56:22.7.6_0: they don’t continue to be reborn and grow old.”
ai-sn56:23.1.2_0: There are, monastics, these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:23.1.4_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:23.1.5_0: These are the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:23.1.6_0: It is because he has truly woken up to these four noble truths that the Realized One is called ‘the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha’.
ai-sn56:23.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:23.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:24.1.2_0: “Mendicants, whatever perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—past,
ai-sn56:24.1.3_0: Whatever perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—whether in the future, all of them truly wake up to the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:24.1.4_0: or present—all of them truly wake up to the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:24.2.2_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:24.2.3_0: Whatever perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas truly wake up—in the past,
ai-sn56:24.2.5_0: or present—all of them truly wake up to the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:24.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:24.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:25.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.
ai-sn56:25.1.2_0: For one who knows and sees what?
ai-sn56:25.1.3_0: The ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:25.1.4_0: That’s how you should know and see in this way.
ai-sn56:25.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:25.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:26.1.1_0: “Mendicants, those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the true comprehension of the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:26.2.2_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:26.2.3_0: Those who you have sympathy for, and those worth listening to—friends and colleagues, relatives and family—should be encouraged, supported, and established in the true comprehension of the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:26.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:26.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:26.3.2_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn56:27.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:27.1.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:27.1.4_0: These are the four noble truths that are real, not unreal, not otherwise.
ai-sn56:27.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:27.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:28.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:28.1.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:28.1.4_0: In this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, the Realized One is the Noble One.
ai-sn56:28.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:28.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:29.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are these four noble truths.
ai-sn56:29.1.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:29.1.4_0: These are the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:29.1.5_0: Of these four noble truths, there is one to be completely understood, one to be given up, one to be realized, and one to be developed.
ai-sn56:29.2.1_0: And what is the noble truth of completely understanding?
ai-sn56:29.2.2_0: The noble truth of suffering should be completely understood. The noble truth of the origin of suffering should be given up. The noble truth of the cessation of suffering should be realized. The noble truth of the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be developed.
ai-sn56:29.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:29.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:30.1.1_0: At one time several mendicants were staying in the land of the Cetis at Sahajāti.
ai-sn56:30.1.2_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several senior mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them:
ai-sn56:30.1.3_0: “Reverends, does someone who sees suffering also see the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering?”
ai-sn56:30.2.1_0: When they said this, Venerable Gavampati said to those senior mendicants:
ai-sn56:30.2.2_0: “Reverends, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
ai-sn56:30.2.3_0: ‘Mendicants, someone who sees suffering also sees suffering, the origin of suffering, and the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:30.2.4_0: Someone who sees the origin of suffering also sees suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:30.2.5_0: Someone who sees the cessation of suffering also sees suffering, the origin of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
ai-sn56:30.2.6_0: Someone who sees the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering also sees suffering, the origin of suffering, and the cessation of suffering.’”
ai-sn56:30.2.8_0: The third sub-chapter on Koṭigāma is finished.
ai-sn56:30.3.2_0: Ending on the ending of defilements,
ai-sn56:30.3.3_0: Likewise the world and the world.
ai-sn56:31.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī in a rosewood forest.
ai-sn56:31.1.2_0: Then the Buddha took a few leaves and addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn56:31.1.5_0: the few leaves in my hand, or those in the forest above me?”
ai-sn56:31.1.6_0: “Sir, the few leaves in your hand are a tiny amount.
ai-sn56:31.1.7_0: There are far more leaves in the forest above.”
ai-sn56:31.1.8_0: “In the same way, there is much more that I have directly known but have not explained to you. What I have explained is a tiny amount.
ai-sn56:31.1.9_0: And why haven’t I explained it?
ai-sn56:31.1.10_0: Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:31.2.2_0: I have explained: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:31.3.1_0: And why have I explained it?
ai-sn56:31.3.2_0: Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:31.4.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:31.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:32.1.2_0: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’
ai-sn56:32.2.1_0: It’s as if someone were to say:
ai-sn56:32.2.2_0: ‘I’ll make a basket out of acacia leaves or pine needles or myrobalan leaves, and use it to carry water or a palm frond.’
ai-sn56:32.2.4_0: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:
ai-sn56:32.2.5_0: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:32.2.5_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering will completely make an end of suffering.’
ai-sn56:32.3.2_0: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, I will completely make an end of suffering.’
ai-sn56:32.4.1_0: It’s as if someone were to say:
ai-sn56:32.4.2_0: ‘I’ll make a basket out of lotus leaves or flame-of-the-forest leaves or camel’s foot creeper leaves, and use it to carry water or a palm frond.’
ai-sn56:32.4.4_0: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:
ai-sn56:32.4.5_0: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:32.4.5_1: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be completely understood.’
ai-sn56:32.5.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:32.5.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:33.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a stick was tossed up in the air. Sometimes it’d fall on its bottom, sometimes the middle, and sometimes the top.
ai-sn56:33.1.2_0: In the same way, sentient beings who are fettered by craving are transmigrated, and who returns to this world once only return from this world and the next.
ai-sn56:33.1.4_0: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:33.1.6_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:33.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:33.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:34.1.1_0: “Mendicants, if your clothes or head were on fire, what would you do about it?”
ai-sn56:34.1.2_0: “Sir, if our clothes or head were on fire, we’d apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness in order to extinguish it.”
ai-sn56:34.2.1_0: “Mendicants, regarding your burning head or clothes with equanimity, not paying attention to them, you should apply intense enthusiasm, effort, zeal, vigor, perseverance, mindfulness, and situational awareness to truly comprehending the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:34.2.3_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:34.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:34.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:35.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose there was a man with a lifespan of a hundred years.
ai-sn56:35.1.3_0: ‘Come now, my good man, they’ll strike you with a hundred spears in the morning, at midday, and in the late afternoon.
ai-sn56:35.1.4_0: And you’ll live for a hundred years being struck with three hundred spears every day. But when a hundred years have passed, you will comprehend the four noble truths for the first time.’
ai-sn56:35.2.1_0: For an earnest gentleman this is sufficient reason to submit.
ai-sn56:35.2.4_0: No first point is found of blows by spears, swords, arrows, and axes.
ai-sn56:35.2.6_0: But the comprehension of the four noble truths doesn’t come with pain or sadness, I say.
ai-sn56:35.2.7_0: Rather, the comprehension of the four noble truths comes only with pleasure and happiness, I say.
ai-sn56:35.2.9_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:35.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:35.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:36.1.1_0: Suppose a person was to strip all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in India, gather them together into one pile,
ai-sn56:36.1.3_0: Then they’d impale the large creatures in the ocean on large stakes; the medium-sized creatures on medium-sized stakes; and the small creatures on small stakes.
ai-sn56:36.1.4_0: They wouldn’t run out of sizable creatures in the ocean before
ai-sn56:36.2.1_0: using up all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in India.
ai-sn56:36.2.2_0: There are far more small creatures in the ocean than this, so it wouldn’t be feasible to impale them on stakes.
ai-sn56:36.2.4_0: Because of the small size of those life-forms.
ai-sn56:36.2.5_0: That’s how big the plane of loss is.
ai-sn56:36.2.6_0: A person accomplished in view, exempt from that vast plane of loss, truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:36.2.6_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:36.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:36.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:36.3.2_0: The sixth offering to an individual.
ai-sn56:37.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the dawn is the forerunner and precursor of the sunrise.
ai-sn56:37.1.2_0: In the same way, right view is the forerunner and precursor of truly comprehending the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:37.1.3_0: A mendicant with right view can expect to truly understand:
ai-sn56:37.1.4_0: I truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ ... ‘This is the origin of suffering’ ... ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’. ... ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:37.1.4_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:37.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:37.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:38.1.1_0: “Mendicants, as long as the moon and sun don’t arise in the world, no great light or great radiance appears.
ai-sn56:38.1.3_0: Day and night aren’t found, nor months and fortnights, nor seasons and years.
ai-sn56:38.2.1_0: But when the moon and the sun arise in the world, a great light, a great radiance appears.
ai-sn56:38.2.3_0: Day and night are found, and months and fortnights, and seasons and years.
ai-sn56:38.2.4_0: In the same way, as long as the Realized One doesn’t arise in the world, no great light or great radiance appears.
ai-sn56:38.3.1_0: But when the Realized One arises in the world, a great light, a great radiance appears.
ai-sn56:38.3.3_0: Then the teaching, advocating, establishing, clarifying, analyzing, and revealing of the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:38.3.5_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:38.4.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:38.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:39.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:39.1.2_0: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:
ai-sn56:39.1.3_0: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’
ai-sn56:39.2.1_0: Suppose there was a light tuft of cotton-wool or kapok which was taken up by the wind and landed on level ground.
ai-sn56:39.2.2_0: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.
ai-sn56:39.2.4_0: It’s because the tuft of cotton-wool is so light.
ai-sn56:39.2.5_0: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:39.2.6_0: They gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:
ai-sn56:39.2.7_0: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’
ai-sn56:39.2.9_0: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:39.3.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:39.3.2_0: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:
ai-sn56:39.3.3_0: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’
ai-sn56:39.4.1_0: Suppose there was an iron pillar or a boundary pillar with deep foundations, firmly embedded, imperturbable and unshakable.
ai-sn56:39.4.2_0: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south,
ai-sn56:39.4.2_3: They couldn’t make it tremor and tremble and quake.
ai-sn56:39.4.4_0: It’s because that boundary pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.
ai-sn56:39.4.5_0: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:39.4.6_0: They don’t gaze up at the face of another ascetic or brahmin, thinking:
ai-sn56:39.4.7_0: ‘Surely this worthy one knows and sees.’
ai-sn56:39.4.9_0: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:39.4.11_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:39.5.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:39.5.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:40.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ ...
ai-sn56:40.1.2_0: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking:
ai-sn56:40.1.3_0: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
ai-sn56:40.1.6_0: If an ascetic or brahmin were to come from the south, she to debate, seeking a debate,
ai-sn56:40.1.7_0: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
ai-sn56:40.2.1_0: Suppose there was a stone pillar, sixteen feet long.
ai-sn56:40.2.2_0: Eight feet were buried underground, and eight above ground.
ai-sn56:40.2.3_0: Even if violent storms were to blow up out of the east, the west, the north, and the south,
ai-sn56:40.2.3_3: They couldn’t make it tremor and tremble and quake.
ai-sn56:40.2.5_0: It’s because that boundary pillar is firmly embedded, with deep foundations.
ai-sn56:40.2.6_0: In the same way, take any mendicant who truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ ...
ai-sn56:40.2.6_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:40.2.7_0: An ascetic or brahmin might come from the east, west, north, or south wanting to debate, seeking a debate, thinking: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
ai-sn56:40.2.10_0: If an ascetic or brahmin were to come from the south, she to debate, seeking a debate,
ai-sn56:40.2.10_1: ‘I’ll refute their doctrine!’ It’s simply impossible for them to legitimately make that mendicant shake or rock or tremble.
ai-sn56:40.2.12_0: It’s because they have clearly seen the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:40.2.14_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:40.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:40.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:40.3.3_0: The fourth sub-chapter on skulls is finished.
ai-sn56:40.4.1_0: a staff, fist, rod, or sword.
ai-sn56:40.4.2_0: and if man and a hundred spears,
ai-sn56:41.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn56:41.1.3_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a certain person left Rājagaha, thinking ‘I’ll speculate about the Sumāgadhā.’
ai-sn56:41.1.3_1: and after going, he sat down on the bank of the lotus pond.
ai-sn56:41.1.4_0: Then that person saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.
ai-sn56:41.1.5_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-sn56:41.1.6_0: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!
ai-sn56:41.1.7_0: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
ai-sn56:41.2.1_0: Then that person entered the city and informed a large crowd,
ai-sn56:41.2.2_0: ‘I’ve gone mad, really, I’ve lost my mind!
ai-sn56:41.2.3_0: I’m seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
ai-sn56:41.2.4_0: ‘But how is it that you’re mad? How have you lost your mind?
ai-sn56:41.2.5_0: And what have you seen that doesn’t exist in the world?’
ai-sn56:41.2.6_0: ‘Sirs, I left Rājagaha, thinking “I’ll speculate about the world.”
ai-sn56:41.2.6_1: and after going, he sat down on the bank of the lotus pond.
ai-sn56:41.2.7_0: Then I saw an army of four divisions enter a lotus stalk.
ai-sn56:41.2.8_0: That’s why I’m mad, that’s why I’ve lost my mind.
ai-sn56:41.2.9_0: And that’s what I’ve seen that doesn’t exist in the world.’
ai-sn56:41.2.10_0: ‘Well, mister, you’re definitely mad, you’ve definitely lost your mind.
ai-sn56:41.2.11_0: And you’re seeing things that don’t exist in the world.’
ai-sn56:41.3.1_0: But what that person saw was in fact real, not unreal.
ai-sn56:41.3.2_0: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
ai-sn56:41.3.3_0: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.
ai-sn56:41.3.4_0: The defeated and terrified demons entered the demon city through the lotus stalk only to confuse the gods.
ai-sn56:41.4.1_0: So mendicants, don’t speculate about the world.
ai-sn56:41.4.2_0: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.
ai-sn56:41.4.4_0: Because those thoughts aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:41.5.1_0: When you think something up, you should think: ‘This is suffering’ ...
ai-sn56:41.5.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:41.5.3_0: Because those thoughts are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn56:41.6.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:41.6.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:42.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
ai-sn56:42.1.2_0: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn56:42.1.3_0: “Come, mendicants, let’s go to Inspiration Peak for the day’s meditation.
ai-sn56:42.1.5_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha came together with several mendicants went to the Peak.
ai-sn56:42.1.6_0: A certain mendicant saw the big cliff there
ai-sn56:42.1.7_0: and after seeing (him), he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-sn56:42.1.8_0: “Sir, that big cliff is really huge and scary.
ai-sn56:42.1.9_0: Is there any other cliff bigger and scarier than this one?”
ai-sn56:42.2.2_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:42.2.3_0: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.2.4_0: Since they take pleasure in such choices, they continue to make them.
ai-sn56:42.2.5_0: Having made choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, they fall down the cliff of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.2.6_0: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.2.7_0: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn56:42.3.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:42.3.2_0: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.3.3_0: Since they don’t take pleasure in such choices, they stop making them.
ai-sn56:42.3.4_0: Having stopped making choices that lead to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, they don’t fall down the cliff of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.3.5_0: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:42.3.6_0: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn56:42.4.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:42.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:43.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there is a hell called ‘The Mighty Fever’.
ai-sn56:43.1.2_0: There, whatever sight you see with your eye is unlikable, not likable;
ai-sn56:43.1.3_0: Whatever sound you hear ... Whatever odor you smell ... Whatever flavor you taste ...
ai-sn56:43.1.5_0: Whatever thought you know with your mind is unlikable, not likable;
ai-sn56:43.1.5_1: They know what is unprotected, not what is wrong.
ai-sn56:43.2.1_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn56:43.2.2_0: “Sir, that fever really is mighty, so very mighty.
ai-sn56:43.2.3_0: Is there any other fever more mighty and terrifying than this one?”
ai-sn56:43.3.2_0: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:43.3.3_0: They take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth ...
ai-sn56:43.3.4_0: They continue to make such choices ...
ai-sn56:43.3.5_0: Having made such choices, they burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:43.3.6_0: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:43.3.7_0: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn56:43.4.1_0: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:43.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:43.4.2_0: They don’t take pleasure in choices that lead to rebirth ...
ai-sn56:43.4.3_0: They don’t continue to make such choices ...
ai-sn56:43.4.4_0: Having stopped making such choices, they don’t burn with the fever of rebirth, old age, and death, of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:43.4.5_0: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
ai-sn56:43.4.6_0: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn56:43.5.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:43.5.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:44.1.2_0: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:44.1.2_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering will completely make an end of suffering.’
ai-sn56:44.2.1_0: It’s as if someone were to say:
ai-sn56:44.2.2_0: ‘After the lower story of a bungalow is built, I will climb up to the upper story.’
ai-sn56:44.2.4_0: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:
ai-sn56:44.2.5_0: ‘Without truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:44.2.5_1: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering will completely make an end of suffering.’
ai-sn56:44.3.2_0: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:44.3.2_1: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be completely understood.’
ai-sn56:44.4.1_0: It’s as if someone were to say:
ai-sn56:44.4.2_0: ‘After the lower story of a bungalow is built, I will climb up to the upper story.’
ai-sn56:44.4.4_0: In the same way, suppose someone were to say:
ai-sn56:44.4.5_0: ‘After truly comprehending the noble truths of suffering,
ai-sn56:44.4.5_1: The practice that leads to the cessation of suffering should be completely understood.’
ai-sn56:44.5.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:44.5.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:45.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-sn56:45.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
ai-sn56:45.1.3_0: He saw several Licchavi youths practicing archery. They were shooting arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.
ai-sn56:45.1.4_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-sn56:45.1.5_0: “The Licchavīs have been extracted, and are self-controlled, who are self-control and famous.
ai-sn56:45.1.6_0: since even a distance of delicates in a distance—hose a filthy opposite sex and free of doubt—made, uncertainties, and undecision.”
ai-sn56:45.2.1_0: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Vesālī.
ai-sn56:45.2.1_2: After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
ai-sn56:45.2.2_0: “Here I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
ai-sn56:45.2.3_0: But I saw several Licchavi youths practicing archery. They were shooting arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing.
ai-sn56:45.2.5_0: ‘The Licchavīs have been seen by the Licchavīs, and are easily performed,
ai-sn56:45.2.6_0: since even an iron ball of strings in a distance, the opportunity will come out and trust.’”
ai-sn56:45.3.2_0: Which is harder and more challenging:
ai-sn56:45.3.3_0: to shoot arrows from a distance through a small keyhole, shot after shot without missing? Or to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip?”
ai-sn56:45.3.4_0: “It’s more difficult and challenging, sir, to take a horsehair split into seven strands and penetrate one tip with another tip.”
ai-sn56:45.3.5_0: “Still, Ānanda, those who truly penetrate suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path penetrate them.
ai-sn56:45.3.5_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:45.4.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:45.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

ai-sn56:46.2.3_0: Is there any other darkness more mighty and terrifying than this one?”

ai-sn56:47.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to throw a yoke with a single hole into the ocean.
ai-sn56:47.1.1_1: And there he said to Kaccāna:
ai-sn56:47.1.1_2: And at the end of every hundred years someone would pour up once every hundred years.
ai-sn56:47.1.3_0: Would one-eyed turtle still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”
ai-sn56:47.1.4_0: “Only after a very long time, sir, if ever.”
ai-sn56:47.2.1_0: “That one-eyed turtle would poke its neck through the hole in that yoke sooner than a hundred years.
ai-sn56:47.3.2_0: Because in that place there’s no principled or moral conduct, and no doing what is good and skillful.
ai-sn56:47.3.3_0: There they just prey on each other, preying on the weak.
ai-sn56:47.3.5_0: It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.
ai-sn56:47.3.7_0: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:47.4.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:47.4.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:48.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose the earth was entirely covered with water.
ai-sn56:48.1.2_0: And a person threw a yoke with a single hole into it.
ai-sn56:48.1.3_0: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.
ai-sn56:48.1.4_0: And there was a one-eyed turtle who popped up once every hundred years.
ai-sn56:48.1.6_0: Would one-eyed turtle still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”
ai-sn56:48.2.1_0: “Mendicants, this is how you find happiness as a human being.
ai-sn56:48.2.2_0: That’s how this Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn56:48.2.3_0: And that’s how unlikely it is for the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One to shine in the world.
ai-sn56:48.2.4_0: And now, mendicants, you have been reborn as a human being. A Realized One has arisen in the world, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha. And the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One shines in the world.
ai-sn56:48.3.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:48.3.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
ai-sn56:49.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place down on Sineru, the king of mountains, seven pebbles the size of mung beans.
ai-sn56:49.1.3_0: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mung beans, or Sineru, the king of mountains?”
ai-sn56:49.1.4_0: “Sir, Sineru, the king of mountains, is certainly more.
ai-sn56:49.1.5_0: The seven pebbles the size of mung beans are tiny.
ai-sn56:49.1.6_0: Compared to Sineru, they don’t count, there’s no comparison, they’re not worth a fraction.”
ai-sn56:49.1.7_0: “In the same way, for a person with comprehension, a noble disciple accomplished in view, the suffering that’s over and done with is more,
ai-sn56:49.1.8_0: Compared to the mass of suffering in the past that’s over and done with, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction, since there are at most seven more lives.
ai-sn56:49.1.9_0: Such a person truly understands about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
ai-sn56:49.1.9_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
ai-sn56:49.2.1_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...
ai-sn56:49.2.1_1: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

ai-sn56:50.1.4_0: “Sir, the portion of Sineru, the king of mountains, that has been worn away and eroded is certainly more.
ai-sn56:50.1.5_0: The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

ai-sn56:51.1.4_0: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more.

ai-sn56:52.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose there was a lotus pond covered with wisdom in full detail. And it was points a league high, full to white, and soft to the brim.
ai-sn56:52.1.2_0: Then a person would pick up some water on the tip of a blade of grass.
ai-sn56:52.1.4_0: Which is more: the water on the tip of the blade of grass, or the water in the lotus pond?”
ai-sn56:52.1.5_0: “Sir, the water in the lotus pond is certainly more. The water on the tip of a blade of grass is tiny.
ai-sn56:52.1.6_0: Compared to the water in the lotus pond, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”
ai-sn56:52.1.7_0: “In the same way, for a noble disciple ...
ai-sn56:52.1.8_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...”
ai-sn56:53.1.1_0: “Mendicants, there are places where the great rivers—the Ganges, Yamuna, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—come together and converge.
ai-sn56:53.1.2_0: Suppose a person was to draw two or three drops of water from such a place.
ai-sn56:53.1.4_0: Which is more: the two or three drops drawn out or the water in the confluence?”
ai-sn56:53.1.5_0: “Sir, the water in the confluence is certainly more.
ai-sn56:53.1.5_1: The two or three drops drawn out are tiny.
ai-sn56:53.1.6_0: Compared to the water in the confluence, it doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, it’s not worth a fraction.”
ai-sn56:53.1.7_0: “In the same way, for a noble disciple ...
ai-sn56:53.1.8_0: That’s why you should practice meditation ...”
